message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Periodic Event-Triggered Adaptive Fuzzy Control for Networked Nonlinear Systems
Paper Abstract: This article addresses the periodic event-triggered adaptive output feedback control problem for networked system with unknown nonlinear dynamics. Based on the output-dependent periodic event-triggered mechanism (PETM), a nonlinear observer is designed to estimate system states, where the fuzzy-logic systems-based approximation method and adaptive technique are employed to approximate and compensate for uncertainties. To enhance resource utilization efficiency in communication channels, a new observer and parameter estimators-dependent parallel PETM is proposed to schedule intermittent packet transmission. Then, a digital controller is designed to reduce frequent control updating. By constructing novel piecewise Lyapunov functional, it is proven that the underlying system states, the observation error signals and parameter estimation signals are semiglobally uniformly ultimately bounded. In addition, the proposed control method is applied to solve the stabilization problem of networked interconnected systems. Finally, a numerical simulation is performed to show the efficiency of the developed control method.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the web search results, I found relevant information about event-triggered control systems. Here's what I found:

Event-triggered systems are a field of study recognized by the IEEE, as evidenced by Maurice Heemels being named Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) in 2016 for contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

While the search results don't provide a detailed definition of event-triggered control specifically, they do show that this is an established area of research in control theory and engineering. Event-triggered control is distinct from time-triggered systems—time-triggered systems are computer systems that execute one or more sets of tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule, whereas event-triggered control operates based on specific events rather than fixed time schedules.

The search results indicate that event-triggered control is an important discipline within control systems engineering, particularly relevant for networked and hybrid systems. If you'd like more detailed technical information about event-triggered control mechanisms, applications, or methodologies, I'd be happy to search for more specific information.

Links: [{"title":"Negative feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Proportional–integral–derivative controller","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional–integral–derivative_controller"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Proportional control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proportional_control"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Voltage regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voltage_regulator"},{"title":"Game controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_controller"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of feedback control output:

## What is Feedback Control Output?

A feedback control or closed-loop controller is a control loop which incorporates feedback and uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.

## How Feedback Control Output Works

The output of the system is fed back through a sensor measurement to a comparison with the reference value, and the controller then takes the error (difference) between the reference and the output to change the inputs to the system under control.(no content)The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Key Characteristics

The control signal is "fed back" as input to the process, which closes the loop.(no content)In linear feedback systems, a control loop including sensors, control algorithms, and actuators is arranged in an attempt to regulate a variable at a setpoint.

## Real-World Example

An everyday example is cruise control on a road vehicle, where the PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Lyapunov stability:

## Overview

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.

## Definition and Concepts

Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium (within a distance) remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.(no content)Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable the system remains stable under small disturbances.

## Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Historical Development

A. M. Lyapunov was a pioneer in successful endeavors to develop a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## Applications

The theory has broad applications in modern control systems, especially for nonlinear systems. The concept of the Lyapunov exponent (related to Lyapunov's First Method of discussing stability) has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Web search results for query: "Networked control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Networked control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system"},{"title":"HVAC control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HVAC_control_system"},{"title":"Systems integrator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Systems_integrator"},{"title":"Concurrent Versions System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concurrent_Versions_System"},{"title":"Emilia Fridman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emilia_Fridman"},{"title":"QLab - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qlab"},{"title":"Roberto Tempo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roberto_Tempo"},{"title":"Direct digital control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_digital_control"},{"title":"Resilient control systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resilient_control_systems"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of networked control systems:

## Definition and Basics

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

## Key Challenges

The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.

## Research Areas

New control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data are some of the relative topics studied in depth.

## Network Technologies

Networked control systems can use various communication technologies, such as Bluetooth, Zigbee, and Z-Wave in wireless applications.

## Design Approaches

Many researchers provided solutions using concepts from several control areas such as robust control, optimal stochastic control, model predictive control, fuzzy logic etc.

New control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data are some of the relative topics studied in depth.

## Network Technologies

Networked control systems can use various communication technologies, such as Bluetooth, Zigbee, and Z-Wave in wireless applications.

## Design Approaches

Many researchers provided solutions using concepts from several control areas such as robust control, optimal stochastic control, model predictive control, fuzzy logic etc.

Based on the search results, here's information about observer control systems:

## Overview

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

## Purpose and Applications

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

A practical example is provided: "the rates and velocities at which vehicles enter and leave the tunnel can be observed directly, but the exact state inside the tunnel can only be estimated."

## Key Concepts

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.(no content)Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

Observer control systems are fundamental to modern control theory and are widely used in applications requiring feedback control where not all system states can be directly measured.

Web search results for query: "Control system adaptive"

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Adaptive system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_system"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Control engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_systems_engineering"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Karl Johan Åström - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_Johan_Åström"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Active suspension - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_suspension"}]

Here are the search results for "Control system adaptive":

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Characteristics

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Technical Foundation

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent. Both of these methods provide update laws that are used to modify estimates in real-time (i.e., as the system operates).

## Applications

Adaptive controls were applied for the first time in the aerospace industry in the 1950s, and have found particular success in that field.(no content)A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control.

## Control Approaches

There are several categories of adaptive control systems, including Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) – incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance and Cautious adaptive controllers – use current SI to modify control law, allowing for SI uncertainty.

I've completed the web search for "Fuzzy logic systems." Here's a comprehensive overview of the search results:

## Overview

Fuzzy logic is a form of many-valued logic related to fuzzy sets.(no content)A fuzzy control system is a control system based on fuzzy logic – a mathematical system that analyzes analog input values in terms of logical variables that take on continuous values between 0 and 1, in contrast to classical or digital logic, which operates on discrete values.

## Key Concepts

In a fuzzy rule, the premise and consequent can be true to a degree, instead of entirely true or entirely false, which is achieved by representing the linguistic variables using fuzzy sets.(no content)A linguistic variable such as age may accept values such as young and its antonym old.

## System Architecture

The most well-known system is the Mamdani rule-based one, which uses the following rules: fuzzify all input values into fuzzy membership functions, execute all applicable rules in the rulebase to compute the fuzzy output functions, and de-fuzzify the fuzzy output functions to get "crisp" output values.

## Applications

Fuzzy logic is used in control systems to allow experts to contribute vague rules such as "if you are close to the destination station and moving fast, increase the train's brake pressure"; these vague rules can then be numerically refined within the system.(no content)It has been used for handwriting recognition in Sony pocket computers, helicopter flight aids, subway system controls, improving automobile fuel efficiency, single-button washing machine controls, automatic power controls in vacuum cleaners, and early recognition of earthquakes.

The search results provide comprehensive information about fuzzy logic systems, their fundamentals, applications, and technical implementations.

## Nonlinear Control Systems

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.

### Definition and Scope

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle and applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.(no content)These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations.

### Key Differences from Linear Control

Linear control theory applies to systems made of devices which obey the superposition principle and are governed by linear differential equations. A major subclass is linear time invariant (LTI) systems, which can be solved by powerful frequency domain mathematical techniques such as the Laplace transform, Fourier transform, Z transform, Bode plot, root locus, and Nyquist stability criterion.

In contrast, the mathematical techniques developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems. These include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.

### Analysis and Design Approaches

If only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

### Practical Example

An example of a nonlinear control system is a thermostat-controlled heating system, where a furnace has a nonlinear response to temperature changes—it is either "on" or "off", it does not have fine control in response to temperature differences that a proportional (linear) device would have.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed all the analysis tasks. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** The paper "Observer-Based Periodic Event-Triggered Adaptive Fuzzy Control for Networked Nonlinear Systems" is classified as a **contribution** because it proposes novel control methods including adaptive fuzzy control, a new observer design, and a periodic event-triggered mechanism.

**Triples Extracted:** I identified and verified 7 key technological and methodological entities from the paper:

1. **Fuzzy logic** (method) - Used for approximating system uncertainties
2. **State observer** (method) - Newly proposed nonlinear observer design
3. **Lyapunov stability** (concept) - Used for proving system stability
4. **Adaptive control** (method) - Applied to handle parameter uncertainties
5. **Negative feedback** (concept) - Used in output feedback control mechanisms
6. **Nonlinear control** (method) - Proposed adaptive techniques for nonlinear systems
7. **Networked control system** (task) - The main control problem addressed

**Validation:** All triples have been verified with correct Wikipedia URLs and passed the validation script successfully.

Sources:
- [Fuzzy logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuzzy_logic)
- [State observer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer)
- [Lyapunov stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability)
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [Negative feedback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_feedback)
- [Nonlinear control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control)
- [Networked control system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Networked_control_system)
